newsitem.title: CANADA: Wheat remains Canada's top crop but loses ground.
newsitem.headline: Wheat remains Canada's top crop but loses ground.

text.p: Wheat remained Canada's top crop in 1996, but its share of total field crop area continued to shrink, Statistics Canada said on Wednesday.
"The decline in wheat acreage was primarily the result of farmers diversifying into other crops," StatsCan's 1996 farm census report said.

Wheat took up 30.7 million acres of Canada's field crop area in 1996, or 35.8 percent of the total -- its smallest share in 20 years. Wheat took up 42.6 percent of total field crop area in 1991 and 43.2 percent in 1986.
"Crop farmers have been diversifying into other crops and livestock to take advantage of export markets, new crop varieties and new processing capacity," StatsCan said.
Hay and fodder was Canada's second largest crop in 1996, occupying 15.3 million acres, up nearly one million acres over 1991.

Farmers grew 2.2 million acres of soybeans in 1996, up 46 percent from 1991, while the area covered by specialty crops like dry field peas rose to 1.3 million acres from 495,649 in 1991 due to export demand.
Exports of dry peas in 1996 reached 800,000 tonnes, four times the quantity exported in 1991, StatsCan said.
